title: City teen Apostolakis looming as future Matilda
body_text:
Alexia Apostolakis grew up idolising Ellie Carpenter and then Clare Hunt.

Now the Melbourne City teenager can dare to dream of joining the gun defensive duo in the Matildas.
Apostolakis, a Young Matilda, moved from Western Sydney ahead of the current A-League Women season to elevate her game.
One of the competition's finest young defenders, Apostolakis is among the potential bolters for Tom Sermanni's squad for next month's SheBelieves Cup.
If the call-up doesn't come then it's not far off.
"That's been a big thing on my mind recently, but I try not to think about it as much," Apostolakis told AAP.
"Like, I know that if I just work on myself and I prepare myself in the best way that will come eventually."
Her City teammate Holly McNamara is also among the hopefuls for a Matildas call-up.
The 22-year-old striker is slowly rediscovering her prodigious talent on the field after suffering a third anterior cruciate ligament tear in 2023 mere days following a Matildas recall.
While having not yet played a full game since making her return in December, McNamara is refusing to discount her chances.
"Anytime that you can go up for selection for your country, you would want to do that," McNamara said.
"I'm in the right headspace at the moment, so hopefully if that comes, that would be amazing."
City coach Michael Matricciani, while remaining pragmatic about her game fitness, could only endorse McNamara.
"Can she go there in two weeks, three weeks time in the break and play 90 minutes? I don't think so," Matricciani said.
"But if she wants to play 60 or off the bench and then get exposed to that level again, then I think definitely they should consider taking her."
Besides teammate McNamara, Apostolakis, who can play as both a central defender and a fullback, has plenty of role models to look to for inspiration.
"Ellie Carpenter has been one of my idols forever," Apostolakis said.
"I remember watching them in Sydney play against Brazil, and she's just always someone that I've idolised.
"Even when I was playing alongside Clare Hunt at Wanderers, she was a big idol for me.
"Her leadership, her dedication to improving herself is something that I love to watch."
Apostolakis is also eligible to play for the Philippines through her mother's side of the family - and has been scoped out for her interest.
"It has come up previously, when 'Staj' (Alen Stajcic) was actually the coach there, but no, it's always been my goal to play for Australia," she said.
"Because I was born here and I grew up here, so it's something I'm very connected with.
"I would love to connect to my roots somehow, but definitely think football-wise, it's definitely Australia for me."
Still just 18, Apostolakis completed her HSC exams while with her City teammates in Thailand for the Women's Asian Champions League group stage.
Now she's able to focus full-time on football.
Apostolakis and McNamara will play a crucial role in attempting to shut down Melbourne Victory's attack in Saturday's table-topping derby clash at Casey Fields.
Australian Associated Press
